Dale_Ann_Bradley:
{{short description|American bluegrass musician|bot=PearBOT 5}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Dale Ann Bradley | image = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alias = | birth_date = | birth_place = | origin = | death_date = | death_place = | genre = | occupation = | instrument = | years_active = | label = [[Compass Records|Compass]], [[Mountain Home Records|Mountain Home]], [[Doobie Shea Records|Doobie Shea]]{{cite news | title =Doobie Shea Records Shutters | newspaper =Billboard | date =July 6, 2004 | url =http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1434148/doobie-shea-records-shutters | accessdate =March 25, 2014 }}
[[Pinecastle Records|Pinecastle]] | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|https://www.daleannbradley.com/}} }} '''Dale Ann Bradley''' is an American [[bluegrass music]]ian. She is a six-time (2007, 2008, 2009, 2011, 2012, and 2021) Female Bluegrass Vocalist of the Year, a distinction given by the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]].{{cite news | last =Halsey | first =Derek | title =Five-time award-winning vocalist Dale Ann Bradley brings all-star band to the Mountaineer Opry | newspaper =The Herald Dispatch| date =March 13, 2014 | url =http://www.herald-dispatch.com/features/x1313365424/Five-time-award-winning-vocalist-Dale-Ann-Bradley-brings-all-star-band-to-the-Mountaineer-Opry | accessdate =March 19, 2014 }} She has released music both as a solo artist and as part of the group New Coon Creek Girls.{{cite web | title =About Dale Ann Bradley | publisher =CMT | url =http://www.cmt.com/artists/dale-ann-bradley/biography/ | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140116074706/http://www.cmt.com/artists/dale-ann-bradley/biography/ | url-status =dead | archive-date =January 16, 2014 | accessdate =March 25, 2014 }} ==Early life== Bradley was born in [[Bell County, Kentucky|Bell County]], Kentucky. Her father was a coal-mining Baptist minister.{{cite news | title =Dale Ann Bradley On Mountain Stage | newspaper =NPR | date =June 9, 2009 | url =https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=106420668| accessdate =March 19, 2014 }} She grew up without running water or electricity until she was a senior in high school.{{cite news | title =A 'Women in Bluegrass Spectacular' will feature Dale Ann Bradley, Most Recent Female Vocalist | newspaper =Southern Maryland News | date =February 18, 2014 | url =http://smnewsnet.com/archives/93464/ | accessdate =March 25, 2014 }} She also lived with heavy religious restrictions with her father being a minister. She received her first guitar at the age of 14, making a guitar pick out of a plastic milk carton to play. As a junior in high school, Bradley met a childhood friend of her mother who was also her new band director at school. He and his wife sang at [[F. D. Roosevelt State Park|Pine Mountain State Park]], located in Pineville, Kentucky, in the summers and invited Bradley to perform with them. She played with the band (Backporch Grass) and recorded a few singles and had the opportunity to perform in front of live audiences. ==Career== Bradley auditioned for the New Coon Creek Girls in 1988 but was unsuccessful. For the next couple of years, she worked as a solo artist before finally joining the group in 1991. She released her first solo album, East Kentucky Morning, in 1997. The album was top ten on both the Bluegrass Unlimited chart and the Gavin Americana chart. In early 2015, Bradley left her record label [[Compass Records]] for Pinecastle Records, with whom she recorded her first solo album.{{cite web |url=http://www.daleann.com/ |title=Dale Ann Bradley & Coon Creek |website=www.daleann.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19991104050852/http://daleann.com/ |archive-date=1999-11-04}} In late 2015, her 7th album, Pocket Full of Keys received a Grammy nomination for Best Bluegrass Album {{Cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees?genre=59|title=Awards Nominations & Winners|date=April 30, 2017}} From 2012 to 2020, Bradley was a member of the all-female bluegrass band [[Sister Sadie (band)|Sister Sadie]]. Their second album received a [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]] nomination in 2019. ==Discography== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:4em;"| Year ! Dale Ann Bradley AllMusic|website = [[AllMusic]]}} | Pinecastle |- | 2023 | ''Kentucky For Me''{{cite web | url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/dale-ann-bradley-releases-the-sun-is-going-to-shine-with-jp-pennington/ | title=Dale Ann Bradley releases the Sun is Going to Shine, with JP Pennington | date=July 25, 2022 }} | Pinecastle |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bradley, Dale Ann}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American women country singers]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Bluegrass musicians from Kentucky]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Kentucky]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Country musicians from Kentucky]] [[Category:21st-century American women singers]] [[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]
